title: 104_hr1753
content:
The Act titled "United States Commemorative Coins Act of 1995" authorizes the minting of 25,000 10 dollar gold coins to commemorate the bicentennial of United States gold coinage. The coins must have a design emblematic of this event and can only be minted until December 31, 1995. The Secretary will mint $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the United Nations founding and President Harry S Truman's role. The $5 gold coins will weigh 8.359 grams, have a diameter of 0.850 inches, and contain 90% gold. The $1 silver coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver. The design of the coins will symbolize the anniversary. The Secretary may issue coins commemorating the 50th anniversary of the United Nations founding and President Harry S Truman's role. Surcharges of $35 per $5 coin and $10 per $1 coin will be included, with proceeds split between the Harry S Truman Library Foundation and the United Nations. The Harry S Truman Library receives 50 percent of proceeds to support educational activities related to the United Nations and the role of the United States. SEC. 103. SMITHSONIAN INSTITUTION. The Secretary will mint $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins in commemoration of the Smithsonian Institution's sesquicentennial. The $5 coins will weigh 8.359 grams, have a diameter of 0.850 inches, and contain 90% gold. The $1 coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver. The design of the coins will reflect the scientific, educational, and cultural significance of the Smithsonian Institution. The Smithsonian Institution will receive surcharges from the sale of commemorative coins minted by the Secretary during a specific period in 1996-1997. Surcharges include $35 per $5 coin and $10 per $1 coin. The Smithsonian Institution will receive surcharges from the sale of commemorative coins minted by the Secretary in 1996-1997, which will be promptly paid to support the National Numismatic Collection at the National Museum of American History. SEC. 104. FRANKLIN DELANO ROOSEVELT. In commemoration of the public opening of the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial in Washington, DC, the Secretary shall mint and issue up to 100,000 5 dollar coins weighing 8.359 grams, with a diameter of 0.850 inches, and containing 90 percent gold and 10 percent alloy. The design of the coins must reflect the leadership and legacy of Franklin Delano Roosevelt. These coins can only be issued between January 1, 1997, and December 31, 1997, with a $35 surcharge per coin included in sales. All surcharges from coin sales go to the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial Commission for its support and maintenance. SEC. 105. YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK. In honor of the 125th anniversary of Yellowstone National Park, the Secretary will mint up to 500,000 1 dollar coins in 1997. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. The design will reflect the park's anniversary, and each coin sold will include a $10 surcharge. The Secretary will mint up to 500,000 1 dollar coins in 1997 to honor the 125th anniversary of Yellowstone National Park. Each coin sold will include a surcharge of $10 per coin, with the surcharges being distributed to the National Park Foundation and Yellowstone National Park. SEC. 106. NATIONAL LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICERS MEMORIAL. The Secretary shall mint and issue up to 500,000 1 dollar coins in honor of law enforcement officers and their families, weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, and containing 90% silver and 10% copper. The design of the coins will symbolize the sacrifices of law enforcement officers and their families. These coins can only be issued between January 1, 1997, and December 31, 1997, with issuance starting no later than May 1, 1997. The Secretary will issue up to 500,000 1 dollar coins honoring law enforcement officers and their families between January 1, 1997, and December 31, 1997, with issuance starting no later than May 1, 1997. Sales of these coins will include a $10 surcharge per coin, with all surcharges going to the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Fund for supporting the memorial and related programs. SEC. 201. General Specifications: The coins minted under this Act are legal tender and considered numismatic items. The term "recipient organization" refers to the designated organization receiving surcharges from coin sales.

SEC. 202. Sources of Bullion. The Secretary obtains gold for minting coins from existing provisions of law and silver only from stockpiles established under a specific Act. The design of coins is specified under Section 203. Section 203 of the Act specifies the design of coins, including the value, year of issuance, and inscriptions like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design is selected by the Secretary in consultation with recipient organizations and the Commission of Fine Arts. SEC. 204. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities. Only 1 facility of the United States Mint may be used to strike any particular combination of denomination and quality of the coins minted under this Act. SEC. 205. SALE OF COINS. The coins shall be sold at a price including face value, surcharge, and cost of designing. Bulk sales at a discount and prepaid orders accepted with a reasonable discount. SEC. 206. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. SEC. 206. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services needed for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 207. AUDITS OF SURCHARGES. The Comptroller General can audit recipient organizations' expenditures related to coins issued under this Act. SEC. 208. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. SEC. 208. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure no net cost to the government for minting and issuing coins under this Act. Payment for coins requires full payment, security, or a guarantee of full payment from a depository institution.
